item.title: Melanie add a quote by Catherine Deneuve
item.description: "I always try to keep that feeling of being on the edge. I'm afraid of knowing too well and seeming mechanical." -- Catherine Deneuve

item.title: Melanie add a quote by Thant Myint-U
item.description: "May there only be peaceful and cheerful Earth Days to come for our beautiful Spaceship Earth as it continues to spin and circle in frigid space with its warm and fragile cargo of animate life." -- Thant Myint-U

item.title: Melanie add a quote by Thomas Wolfe
item.description: "The modern picture of the artist began to form: The poor, but free spirit, plebeian but aspiring only to be classless, to cut himself forever free from the bonds of the greedy bourgeoisie, to be whatever the fat burghers feared most, to cross the line wherever they drew it, to look at the world in a way they couldn't see, to be high, live low, stay young forever -- in short, to be the bohemian." -- Thomas Wolfe

item.title: Melanie add a quote by Oscar Levant
item.description: "Underneath this flabby exterior is an enormous lack of character." -- Oscar Levant

item.title: Melanie add a quote by D.H. Lawrence
item.description: "One watches them on the seashore, all the people, and there is something pathetic, almost wistful in them, as if they wished their lives did not add up to this scaly nullity of possession, but as if they could not escape. It is a dragon that has devoured us all: these obscene, scaly houses, this insatiable struggle and desire to possess, to possess always and in spite of everything, this need to be an owner, lest one be owned. It is too hideous and nauseating. Owners and owned, they are like the two sides of a ghastly disease. One feels a sort of madness come over one, as if the world had become hell. But it is only superimposed: it is only a temporary disease. It can be cleaned away." -- D.H. Lawrence

item.title: Melanie add a quote by Friedrich Nietzsche
item.description: "There is always some madness in love. But there is also always some reason in madness." -- Friedrich Nietzsche
